OMG -I know I’m a little late to the party here, and there’s probably no body left here to read this - this is an awesome topic, but you missed some of the coolest stuff about this.  First, you explain the fact that the baby’s heart bypasses the lungs when in the womb, but you don’t explain that it is bypassing because the baby’s system is pumping the baby’s blood through the umbilical cord to the placenta so that it can get oxygenated there.  And the realization that the only way the baby’s blood could possibly get oxygenated at the placenta is because the baby’s blood must have a higher affinity for binding oxygen than the mother’s blood or else it wouldn’t be able to gather oxygen for the baby to use in the womb. And consider that once the baby’s blood has higher binding affinity for oxygen, what that could mean once it hits 20% oxygen in the atmosphere at the lung interface at birth.   Which leads to the incredible fact that the baby converts it’s entire blood from higher oxygen affinity prenatal blood to regular blood that works with lungs and atmosphere incredibly fast right after that first breath. Yeah.  If you think what that takes on a molecular level and on a  physiological level, it is freakin awesome.

Fetuses do not deficate in the womb, most waste products leave via the umbilical cord. Red blood cells which have been replaced are stored in the fetus until he or she is born at which point they have their first poo which is called a meconium. It is black and very thick and is colloquially called the "tar poo." The colour is due to a pigment in red blood cells which is highly concentrated in the meconium and so turns it black. Normally the concentration is lower and so they are brown

The baby doesnt actually "breathe" its own poop and urine...its just that the waste from the baby is in the amniotic fluid, which in turn freely flows into the baby's lungs.  No O2 is actually exchanged from the amniotic fluid.  A baby doesnt "breathe" at all really.  The O2 comes from the mother via the umbilical cord.

I was doing a little research on Ps 139:13, the word translated "Womb" was not the typical or literal word in Hebrew or Arabic for Womb but a derivative of the Hebrew word Sakak, meaning screen or fence.  The actual word used often is translated enclosure (Strongs 5526-7), so it would obviously be the mothers womb, but why didn't the original writer just use the word womb (Strongs 990).  It is as if he is highlighting protection or the structure of things.

@rng43 no he is not. I'm sorry but also trained people make mistakes.
Before birth, the lungs are filled with a liquid that they produce themselves which contains chlorides, some proteins, mucus and surfactant. This liquid is not "squeezed out" but resorbed at the moment of birth into capillaries and lymphatic channels with only the surfactant remaining preventing the lung from collapsing.
Amniotic fluid is swallowed (400mL/day) not inhaled.
And also the baby does not "poop" in uterus.

I'm afraid I have to refute that doctor's intel on unborn babies:
- lungs are fully collapsed
- there's no amniotic liquid in the lungs
- there's no *poop* in the amniotic liquid
- the baby does not breath liquid at any time
- the premature lungs produce a secretion of their own, with a high concentration in proteins
- the lungs are not "squeezed" empty during birth, because they already are
